question.html:
Determine the moment about point O in (${{params.unitsForce}} {{params.unitsDist}}$) caused by the force $ \mathbf{F} = {{params.force}}$ $ {{params.unitsForce}}$ acting on the beam.

Let the lengths $\mathbf{L}_1 = {{params.l1}}$ $ {{params.unitsDist}} $, $\mathbf{L}_2 = {{params.l2}}$ $ {{params.unitsDist}} $, $\mathbf{L}_3 = {{params.l3}}$ $ {{params.unitsDist}} $

and $\mathbf{V}_1 = {{params.v1}}$ $ {{params.unitsDist}} $, $\mathbf{V}_2 = {{params.v2}}$ $ {{params.unitsDist}} $, $\mathbf{V}_3 = {{params.v3}}$ $ {{params.unitsDist}} $
solution.html:
First, you must identify the force vector. The red vector in the picture is just there to show the location and direction of the force, but it is not the actual force vector. In order to obtain the force vector you must multiply the force $\mathbf{F} = {{params.force}} $ to the unit vector of the red vector. To obtain the unit vector of the red vector, you must identify the location of the head and tail of the red vector. In our case, the tail of the red vector is equal to $ L_2 \hat{i} + L_1 \hat{j} + L_3 \hat{k}$ and the head of the red vector is equal to $ V_2 \hat{i} + V_1 \hat{j} + V_3 \hat{k}$. Now we can find the direction of the red vector by moving from the tail to the head. Moving from the tail to the head $ \implies (V_2 - L_2 ) \hat{i} + (V_1 - L_1 ) \hat{j} + (V_3 - L_3) \hat{k} $. Now that we have the direction we can divide the length of the vector by itself to obtain the unit vector. $ \frac {(V_2 - L_2 ) \hat{i} + (V_1 - L_1 ) \hat{j} + (V_3 - L_3) \hat{k}}{\sqrt{(V_2 - L_2 )^2 + (V_1 - L_1 )^2 + (V_3 - L_3)^2}} $
    Now all we have to do is multiply the force by the unit vetcor.
  • $\mathbf{\vec{F}} = \mathbf(F) \frac {(V_2 - L_2 ) \hat{i} + (V_1 - L_1 ) \hat{j} + (V_3 - L_3) \hat{k}}{\sqrt{(V_2 - L_2 )^2 + (V_1 - L_1 )^2 + (V_3 - L_3)^2}} $
    • Now that we have the true force vector we can now take the moment about point O using the cross product $M_o = \vec{d} X \vec{F} $
    When computing the moment about point O using the cross product we must chose any distance ($\vec{d}$) starting from the point O and ending anywhere along the line of action of the force vector. In our case we can just use the blue beam since it starts at point o and ends at the tail of the force vector.
  • $\vec{d} = L_2 \hat{i} +L_1 \hat{j} + L_3 \hat{k}$
  • $M_o = \vec{d} X \vec{F} $ $\implies $ $M_o = (L_2, L_1,L_3) X (F_x,F_y,F_z)$ $\implies $ $M_o = ({{correct_answers.momenti}}) \hat{i} + ({{correct_answers.momentj}}) \hat{j} + ({{correct_answers.momentk}}) \hat{k} $

and $\mathbf{v}_1 = 5$ $m$, $\mathbf{v}_2 = 6$ $m$, $\mathbf{v}_3 = 7$ $m$
title: 3d moments

question.html:
Compute the moment about the point O in (${{params.unitsForce}} {{params.unitsDist}}$) as result of the force $ \mathbf{F} = {{params.force}}$ $ {{params.unitsForce}}$ acting at the end of the beam.

Let the lengths $ \mathbf{L}_1 = {{params.l1}}$ ${{params.unitsDist}} $, $ \mathbf{L}_2 = {{params.l2}}$ ${{params.unitsDist}} $, and $ \mathbf{L}_3 = {{params.l3}}$ ${{params.unitsDist}} $
solution.html:
First, you must identify the force vector. The red vector in the picture is just there to show the location and direction of the force, but it is not the actual force vector. In order to obtain the force vector you must multiply the force $\mathbf{F} = {{params.force}} $ to the unit vector of the red vector. To obtain the unit vector of the red vector, you must identify two locations along the line of action of the red vector. In our case, the first point can be the tail of the red vector, which is equal to $ L_1 \hat{i} + L_1 \hat{j} + 0 \hat{k}$, lets call this $\vec{T}$ and for our second point we can use a point along the line of action which is equal to $ (L_1+L_2) \hat{i} + 0 \hat{j} - L_3 \hat{k}$, lets call this $\vec{R}$. Now we can find the direction of the red vector by moving from the tail to our second point. Moving from the tail $\vec{T}$ to our second point $\vec{R}$ $ \implies \vec{R}-\vec{T} = ((L_2 + L_1)-L_1 ) \hat{i} + (0-L_1) \hat{j} + (-L_3-0 )\hat{k} = L_2 \hat{i} - L_1 \hat{j} - L_3\hat{k} $. Now that we have the direction we can divide the length of the vector by itself to obtain the unit vector. $ \frac {L_2 \hat{i} - L_1 \hat{j} - L_3\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(L_2)^2 + (L_1)^2 + (L_3)^2}} $
    Now all we have to do is multiply the force by the unit vector.
  • $\mathbf{\vec{F}} = \mathbf(F) \frac {L_2 \hat{i} - L_1 \hat{j} - L_3\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(L_2)^2 + (L_1)^2 + (L_3)^2}} $
    • Now that we have the true force vector we can now take the moment about point O using the cross product $M_o = \vec{R} X \vec{F} $
  • Note: This statement is also true $M_o = \vec{T} X \vec{F} $
  • It is important to note that when computing the moment about o we chose a vector that starts at o and ends somewhere along the line of action of the force vector ($\vec{F}$). Take a look at the picture and notice the black dotted line, that line represents the line of action of the force vector. Any vector that starts at o and ends at the line will for computing the moment about point o. That is why both of these statements are true $ \implies M_o = \vec{T} X \vec{F} = \vec{R} X \vec{F}$.

Given:  Force: F = specific value N (for example) Lengths: L1 = specific value m (for example) L2 = specific value m (for example) L3 = specific value m (for example) Determine:  Moment about point O in the i direction Moment about point O in the j direction Moment about point O in the k direction

question.html:
Determine the resultant moment produced by the forces $\mathbf{F}_R = {{params.forceR}}$ ${{params.unitsForce}} $ and $\mathbf{F}_G = {{params.forceG}}$ ${{params.unitsForce}} $ about point O in (${{params.unitsForce}} {{params.unitsDist}}$).

Let the lengths $ \mathbf{L}_1 = {{params.l1}}$ ${{params.unitsDist}} $, $ \mathbf{L}_2 = {{params.l2}}$ ${{params.unitsDist}} $, and $ \mathbf{L}_3 = {{params.l3}}$ ${{params.unitsDist}} $
solution.html:
First identify the unit vectors of both the red and green force vectors. To find the unit vectors of both the green and red force vectors first you must find the direction of the vector. You can find the direction of the vectors by identifying two points along the line of action of each vector. Lable the point where the two forces are coming out of (C). And lable the ends of the ropes that are on the ground points R and G. R for the red force and G for the green force. Now to find the direction you can do R-C and G-C
    finding direction of green and red force vectors.
  • Red vector: R-C = $(L_2,-L_3,0) - (0,0,L_1)$ = $(L_2,-L_3,-L_1)$
  • Green vector: G-C = $ (0,L_3,0) - (0,0,L_1)$ = $(0,L_3,-L_1) $
    • Now that we have the direction of both of the vectors we can find the unit vectors by dividing the lengths of the vectors by its self.
  • Unit vector R: $\vec{U}_R $ = $\frac{(L_2,-L_3,-L_1) }{\sqrt{(L_2)^2+(L_3)^2+(L_1)^2}}$
  • Unit vector G: $\vec{U}_G $ = $\frac{(0,L_3,-L_1)}{\sqrt{(L_3)^2+ (L_1)^2}}$
    • Now that we have the unit vectors we can finally find the force vectors $\vec{F}_R$ and $\vec{F}_G$
  • $\vec{F}_R$ = $(\mathbf{F}_R)(\vec{U}_R )$ = $(\mathbf{F}_R) \frac{(L_2,-L_3,-L_1) }{\sqrt{(L_2)^2+(L_3)^2+(L_1)^2}}$
  • $\vec{F}_G$ = $(\mathbf{F}_G)(\vec{U}_G )$ = $(\mathbf{F}_G) \frac{(0,L_3,-L_1)}{\sqrt{(L_3)^2+ (L_1)^2}}$
  • It is important to note that when computing the moment about o we chose a vector that starts at o and ends somewhere along the line of action of the force vectors. In our case the vector that starts at o and ends along the line of action of the force vectors is $\vec{d} = 0\hat{i}+0\hat{j}+L_1\hat{k}$
  • $M_o = M_R + M_G$ = $ [\vec{d} X \vec{F}_R] + [\vec{d} X \vec{F}_G] $

title: 3d moments

question.html:
Determine the resultant moments produced by the forces $\mathbf{F}_R = {{params.forceR}}$ ${{params.unitsForce}} $, $\mathbf{F}_G = {{params.forceG}}$ ${{params.unitsForce}} $,and $\mathbf{F}_P = {{params.forceP}}$ ${{params.unitsForce}} $ about each axis in (${{params.unitsForce}} {{params.unitsDist}}$).

Let the lengths $ \mathbf{L}_1 = {{params.l1}}$ ${{params.unitsDist}} $ and $ \mathbf{L}_2 = {{params.l2}}$ ${{params.unitsDist}} $

Note: Be sure to make clockwise rotation negitive (-) and counter clockwise rotation as positive (+)
solution.html:
Identify which forces will have an effect along each of the axis Any force that is parallel to the axises will not induce a moment about that axis.
    Forces that have a moment about each axis:
  • X-axis: $F_R,F_P,F_P,$ and $F_G$
  • Y-axis: $ F_G$ and $F_G $
  • Z-axis: $F_P,F_G,$ and $F_R$
    • Now that you have the forces that can cause a moment about each axis, you can multiply them by their distance away from the axis to fidn the moment.
    Find Moment about eahc axis.
  • Moment X-axis: $\Sigma{M}_x=(L_1)(F_R) + (L_1)(F_P)+(L_1)(F_G)-(L_1)(F_P)$
  • Moment Y-axis: $\Sigma{M}_y = -(L_2)(F_G)-(L_1)(F_G)$
  • Moment Z-axis: $\Sigma{M}_z = (L_2)(F_P)-(L_1)(F_G)-(L_1)(F_R)$
    • Note: counter clockwise rotation is denoted as positve(+) while clockwise rotation is negative (-)

question.html:
Compute the missing force vector that will allow for static equilibrium.

Provide the Magnitude of the force and the unit vector of the missing force vector.

Let the known forces be $\mathbf{F}_R = {{params.fr}} {{params.unitsForce}}$, $\mathbf{F}_O = {{params.fo}} {{params.unitsForce}}$, $\mathbf{F}_P = {{params.fp}} {{params.unitsForce}}$, and $\mathbf{F}_B = {{params.fb}} {{params.unitsForce}}$.

And let the lengths be $\mathbf{L}_1 = {{params.l1}} {{params.unitsDist}}$, $\mathbf{L}_2 = {{params.l2}} {{params.unitsDist}}$, and $\mathbf{L}_3 = {{params.l3}} {{params.unitsDist}}$.
solution.html:
The first step is to set convert all of the forces into forces vectors.This can be done by multiplying the force magnitude by the unit vector that follows the path of the force. To compute the unit vector all you have to due is divide the length of the vector by its self.
    Computing the Force vectors:
  • $\vec{F}_O = (F_O)(\vec{U}_O)$. let the unit vector $\vec{U}_O = \frac{-L_3\hat{i}-L_1\hat{j}+L_1\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(L_3)^2+(L_1)^2+(L_1)^2}}$

    • So the force vector $\vec{F}_O = (F_O)\frac{-L_3\hat{i}-L_1\hat{j}+L_1\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(L_3)^2+(L_1)^2+(L_1)^2}}$.

  • $\vec{F}_P = (F_P)(\vec{U}_P)$. let the unit vector $\vec{U}_P = \frac{-L_2\hat{i}+L_2\hat{j}+0\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(L_2)^2+(L_2)^2}}$ .

    • So the force vector $\vec{F}_P = (F_P) \frac{-L_2\hat{i}+L_2\hat{j}+0\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(L_2)^2+(L_2)^2}}$.

  • $\vec{F}_B = (F_B)(\vec{U}_B)$. let the unit vector $\vec{U}_B = \frac{L_2\hat{i}+L_1\hat{j}+L_2\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(L_2)^2+(L_2)^2+(L_1)^2}}$ .

    • So the force vector $\vec{F}_B = (F_B) \frac{L_2\hat{i}+L_1\hat{j}+L_2\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(L_2)^2+(L_2)^2+(L_1)^2}}$

  • $\vec{F}_R = (F_R)(\vec{U}_R)$. let the unit vector $\vec{U}_R = \frac{L_2\hat{i}-L_2\hat{j}-L_3\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(L_2)^2+(L_2)^2+(L_3)^2}}$ .

    • So the force vector $\vec{F}_R = (F_R) \frac{L_2\hat{i}-L_2\hat{j}-L_3\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(L_2)^2+(L_2)^2+(L_3)^2}}$

  • Now that you have all of the force vectors, set up the static equilibrium force equations.
    Setting up static equilibrium force equations:
  • $\Sigma{F}_x= 0 \implies -\vec{F}_O\hat{i}-\vec{F}_P\hat{i}+\vec{F}_B\hat{i}+\vec{F}_R\hat{i}+\vec{F}\hat{i} = 0$
  • $\Sigma{F}_y= 0 \implies -\vec{F}_O\hat{j}+\vec{F}_P\hat{j}+\vec{F}_B\hat{j}-\vec{F}_R\hat{j}+\vec{F}\hat{j} = 0$
  • $\Sigma{F}_z= 0 \implies \vec{F}_O\hat{z}+\vec{F}_B\hat{z}-\vec{F}_R\hat{z}+\vec{F}\hat{z} = 0$

    • Where $\vec{F}$ is the messing vector we want to find.

    Solving each equation for $\vec{F}\hat{i}$,$\vec{F}\hat{j}$, and $\vec{F}\hat{k}$

  • $\vec{F}\hat{i} = \vec{F}_O\hat{i}+\vec{F}_P\hat{i}-\vec{F}_B\hat{i}-\vec{F}_R\hat{i}$
  • $\vec{F}\hat{j} = \vec{F}_O\hat{j}+\vec{F}_R-\vec{F}_P\hat{j}\hat{j}-\vec{F}_B\hat{j}$
  • $\vec{F}\hat{k} = -\vec{F}_O\hat{k}-\vec{F}_B\hat{k}+\vec{F}_F\hat{k}$
    • Now that you have the missing vector, compute the magnitude and the unit vector.
    Computing magnitude:
  • $F = \sqrt{\vec{F}\hat{i}^2+\vec{F}\hat{j}^2+\vec{F}\hat{k}^2} = {{correct_answers.F}} {{params.unitsForce}}$.
    • Computing unit vector:
  • $\vec{U}_F = \frac{\vec{F}\hat{i}+\vec{F}\hat{j}+\vec{F}\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(\vec{F}\hat{i})^2+(\vec{F}\hat{j})^2+(\vec{F}\hat{k})^2}}$
  • $\vec{U}_F \hat{i} = {{correct_answers.Ufx}}$
  • $\vec{U}_F \hat{j} = {{correct_answers.Ufy}}$
  • $\vec{U}_F \hat{k} = {{correct_answers.Ufz}}$

question.html:
Determine the tension in each cable in order to support the weight $\mathbf{W} = {{params.weight}} {{params.unitsForce}}$.

Let the lengths be $\mathbf{L}_1 = {{params.l1}} {{params.unitsDist}}$, $\mathbf{L}_2 = {{params.l2}} {{params.unitsDist}}$, and $\mathbf{L}_3 = {{params.l3}} {{params.unitsDist}}$.
solution.html:
First you have to compute the vector expressions for the tensions $T_B$ , $T_C$ and $T_D$. This can be done by multiplying the tension magnitude by the unit vector that follows the path of the tension. To compute the unit vector all you have to due is divide the length of the vector by its self.
    Computing the tension vectors:
  • $\vec{T}_B = (T_B)(\vec{U}_B)$. let the unit vector $\vec{U}_B = \frac{0\hat{i}-L_3\hat{j}+L_2\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(L_3)^2+(L_2)^2}}$

    • So the tension vector $\vec{T}_B = (T_B)\frac{0\hat{i}-L_3\hat{j}+L_2\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(L_3)^2+(L_2)^2}}$

  • $\vec{T}_C = (T_C)(\vec{U}_C)$. let the unit vector $\vec{U}_C = \frac{\frac{L_1}{2}\hat{i}+L_1\hat{j}+0\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(\frac{L_1}{2})^2+(L_1)^2}}$

    • So the tension vector $\vec{T}_C = (T_C)\frac{\frac{L_1}{2}\hat{i}+L_1\hat{j}+0\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(\frac{L_1}{2})^2+(L_1)^2}}$

  • $\vec{T}_D = (T_D)(\vec{U}_D)$. let the unit vector $\vec{U}_D = \frac{-\frac{L_1}{2}\hat{i}+L_1\hat{j}+0\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(\frac{L_1}{2})^2+(L_1)^2}}$

    • So the tension vector $\vec{T}_D = (T_D)\frac{-\frac{L_1}{2}\hat{i}+L_1\hat{j}+0\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(\frac{L_1}{2})^2+(L_1)^2}}$

  • Now that you have all of the force vectors, set up the static equilibrium force equations.
    Setting up static equilibrium force equations:
  • $\Sigma{F}_x= 0 \implies \vec{T}_D\hat{i}-\vec{T}_C\hat{i}=0$
  • $\Sigma{F}_y= 0 \implies \vec{T}_D\hat{j}+\vec{T}_C\hat{j}+\vec{T}_B\hat{j}=0$
  • $\Sigma{F}_z= 0 \implies \vec{T}_B\hat{k} - W=0$

    • Now you can solve for the tension in each cable.

    Solving each equation for $T_B$,$T_C$, and $T_D$ you should get:

  • ${T}_B = {{correct_answers.TAB}} {{params.unitsForce}}$
  • ${T}_C = {{correct_answers.TAC}} {{params.unitsForce}}$
  • ${T}_D = {{correct_answers.TAD}} {{params.unitsForce}tension$
question:
determine the tension in each cable in order to support the weight $\mathbf{w} = 500 \, \text{n}$.

question.html:
The three cables have a maximum tesnion of ${{params.tmax}} {{params.unitsForce}}$.

Determine the maximum weight the yellow plate can be without breaking any cables.

Let the lengths be $\mathbf{L}_1 = {{params.l1}} {{params.unitsDist}}$, $\mathbf{L}_2 = {{params.l2}} {{params.unitsDist}}$, and $\mathbf{L}_3 = {{params.l3}} {{params.unitsDist}}$.
solution.html:
First you have to compute the vector expressions for the tensions $T_B$ , $T_C$ and $T_D$. This can be done by multiplying the tension magnitude by the unit vector that follows the path of the tension. To compute the unit vector all you have to due is divide the length of the vector by its self.
    Computing the tension vectors:
  • $\vec{T}_B = (T_B)(\vec{U}_B)$. let the unit vector $\vec{U}_B = \frac{(L_3-L_1)\hat{i}+L_1\hat{j}+2L_1\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(L_3-L_1)^2+(L_1)^2+(2L_1)^2}}$

    • So the tension vector $\vec{T}_B = (T_B)\frac{(L_3-L_1)\hat{i}+L_1\hat{j}+2L_1\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(L_3-L_1)^2+(L_1)^2+(2L_1)^2}}$

  • $\vec{T}_C = (T_C)(\vec{U}_C)$. let the unit vector $\vec{U}_C = \frac{L_1\hat{i}+(L_1-L_3)\hat{j}+2L_1\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(L_1)^2+(L_1-L_3)^2+(2L_1)^2}}$

    • So the tension vector $\vec{T}_C = (T_C)\frac{L_1\hat{i}+(L_1-L_3)\hat{j}+2L_1\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(L_1)^2+(L_1-L_3)^2+(2L_1)^2}}$

  • $\vec{T}_D = (T_D)(\vec{U}_D)$. let the unit vector $\vec{U}_D = \frac{L_1\hat{i}+(L_3-L_1)\hat{j}+2L_1\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(L_1)^2+(L_3-L_1)^2+(2L_1)^2}}$

    • So the tension vector $\vec{T}_D = (T_D)\frac{L_1\hat{i}+(L_3-L_1)\hat{j}+2L_1\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(L_1)^2+(L_3-L_1)^2+(2L_1)^2}}$

  • Now that you have all of the force vectors, set up the static equilibrium force equations.
    Setting up static equilibrium force equations:
  • $\Sigma{F}_x= 0 \implies -\vec{T}_B\hat{i}+\vec{T}_D\hat{i}+\vec{T}_C\hat{i}=0$
  • $\Sigma{F}_y= 0 \implies \vec{T}_B\hat{j}+\vec{T}_C\hat{j}-\vec{T}_D\hat{j}=0$
  • $\Sigma{F}_z= 0 \implies \vec{T}_B\hat{k}+\vec{T}_D\hat{k}+\vec{T}_C\hat{k}-weight = 0$

    • Now you can solve for the tension in each cable with the assumption that one of the cables is going to holding the maximum tesnion just before it breaks.

    Lets assume that $T_B$ will holding the max tension, that is ${{params.tmax}} {{params.unitsForce}} $

    With this assumption we can set $T_B = {{params.tmax}} {{params.unitsForce}}$. This leaves us with three equations and three unkowns.

    Solving equations using our assumption we get:

  • ${T}_B = {{params.tmax}} {{params.unitsForce}}$
  • ${T}_D = {{params.tmax}} {{params.unitsForce}}$
  • ${T}_C = 0 $
  • $Max Weight ={{params.weight}} {{params.unitsForce}}$
question:
the three cables have a maximum tension of $500 n$.
determine the maximum weight the yellow plate can be without breaking any cables.
let the lengths be $\mathbf{l}_1 = 2 m$, $\mathbf{l}_2 = 3 m$, and $\mathbf{l}_3 = 4 m$.
title: 3d statics

question.html:
There are three cables holding up the weight at point O.

Cables A and B have springs hooked up to them with a spring constant $\mathbf{K} = {{params.k}}$ $ {{params.unitsForcee}}$.

Determine the stretch in the spings while they hold up the weight $\mathbf{W} = {{params.weight}} {{params.unitsForce}}$.

let the lengths be $\mathbf{L}_1 = {{params.l1}} {{params.unitsDist}}$ and $\mathbf{L}_2 = {{params.l2}} {{params.unitsDist}}$

Note: cables A and B travel along the x and y axis.
solution.html:
First you have to compute the vector expressions for the tensions $T_A$ , $T_B$ and $T_C$. This can be done by multiplying the tension magnitude by the unit vector that follows the path of the tension. To compute the unit vector all you have to due is divide the length of the vector by its self.
    Computing the tension vectors:
  • $\vec{T}_A = (T_A)(\vec{U}_A)$. let the unit vector $\vec{U}_A = \frac{0\hat{i}-L\hat{j}+0\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(L)^2}} = 0\hat{i}-1\hat{j}+0\hat{k}$

    • So the tension vector $\vec{T}_A = (T_A)(0\hat{i}-1\hat{j}+0\hat{k})$

  • $\vec{T}_B = (T_B)(\vec{U}_B)$. let the unit vector $\vec{U}_B = \frac{-L\hat{i}+0\hat{j}+0\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(L)^2}} = -1\hat{i}+0\hat{j}+0\hat{k}$

    • So the tension vector $\vec{T}_B = (T_B)(-1\hat{i}+0\hat{j}+0\hat{k})$

  • $\vec{T}_C = (T_C)(\vec{U}_C)$. let the unit vector $\vec{U}_C = \frac{L_1\hat{i}+L_2\hat{j}+L_3\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(L_1)^2+(L_2)^2+(L_3)^2}}$

    • So the tension vector $\vec{T}_D = (T_D)\frac{L_1\hat{i}+L_2\hat{j}+L_3\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(L_1)^2+(L_2)^2+(L_3)^2}}$

  • Now that you have all of the force vectors, set up the static equilibrium force equations.
    Setting up static equilibrium force equations:
  • $\Sigma{F}_x= 0 \implies -\vec{T}_B\hat{i}+\vec{T}_C\hat{i}=0$
  • $\Sigma{F}_y= 0 \implies -\vec{T}_A\hat{j}+\vec{T}_C\hat{j}=0$
  • $\Sigma{F}_z= 0 \implies \vec{T}_C\hat{k} - W = 0$

    • Now you can solve for the tension in each cable.

    Solving force equations:

  • ${T}_C = \frac{W}{\hat{k}} $
    • Where $\hat{k}$ is the k component of $\vec{U}_C$

    Now we can solve for tension A and B:

  • $T_B = \vec{T}_C\hat{i} $
  • $T_A =\vec{T}_C\hat{j} $
    • Now that we have tension A and B, we can find the stretch in the springs.

    Finding stretch in springs using $F = (k)(\Delta x)$

  • $(\Delta x)$ for spring A $= \frac{T_A}{k} = {{params.Xa}} {{params.unitsDist}} $
  • $(\Delta x)$ for spring B $= \frac{T_B}{k} = {{params.Xb}} {{params.unitsDist}} $
question:
there are three cables holding up the weight at point o.
cables a and b have springs hooked up to them with a spring constant $\mathbf{k} = 200 \, \text{n/m}$.
determine the stretch in the spings while they hold up the weight $\mathbf{w} = 500 \, \text{n}$.
let the lengths be $\mathbf{l}_1 = 2 \, \text{m}$ and $\mathbf{l}_2 = 3 \, \text{m}$ 
note: cables a and b travel along the x and y axis.
title: 3d statics

question.html:
Compute the magnitude of the reaction forces at points B,D,and F caused by the weight (W).

Let $ \mathbf{W} = {{params.weight}} {{params.unitsForce}}$ and let the lengths $ \mathbf {L}_1 = {{params.length1}} {{params.unitsDist}}$ , $ \mathbf{L}_2 = {{params.length2}} {{params.unitsDist}}$ , $ \mathbf{L}_3 = {{params.length3}} {{params.unitsDist}}$
solution.html:
Break up the system into 3 parts and write the appropriate reaction forces at each point. Use member AB to solve for the reaction force at point B.
    Solving for the reaction force $B_r$:Using FBD of AB
  • $\Sigma M_A = 0 \implies B_r$ Sin(60) $L_1$ - W($L_1+L_2$)= 0, $\implies B_r = \frac {W(L_1+L_2)}{Sin(\theta) L_1}$
  • $B_r = {{correct_answers.reactionB}}$ ${{params.unitsForce}}$
    • Now that you have the reaction force at point B try and find the reaction force at D.
    Reaction force at D: Using member BD
  • $\Sigma F_x = 0 \implies -B_r +D_r = 0 \implies D_r = B_r$
  • $D_r = {{correct_answers.reactionD}}$ ${{params.unitsForce}}$
    • Using $D_r$ find the reaction forces at F.
    Reaction forces at F: using memeber DC
  • $\Sigma M_C = 0 \implies D_r$ Sin(60)($L_3+L_3$) - $F_r(L_3) = 0 \implies F_r = \frac {D_r Sin(60)(L_3+L_3)}{L_3}$
  • $F_r = {{correct_answers.reactionF}}$ ${{params.unitsForce}}$
question: Refer to the diagram labeled "reaction.png".  Compute the magnitude of the reaction forces at points B, D, and F due to the weight   W.  Given:  Weight,   = 500 W=500 N Lengths:  1 = 2 L  1   =2 m  2 = 3 L  2   =3 m  3 = 1.5 L  3   =1.5 m Determine:  Reaction at pin B. Reaction at Pin D. Reaction at roller F.
title: Frames and machines

question.html:
The Frame supports the load $ \mathbf{W} = {{params.W}} {{params.unitsForce}}$.

Neglecting the weights of the members and compute the magnitude of the horizontal and verticle components of all forces acting at points A,B,C,D,E,and F.

Let the lengths $ \mathbf{L}_1 = {{params.l1}} {{params.unitsDist}} $, $ \mathbf{L}_2 = {{params.l2}} {{params.unitsDist}}$, $ \mathbf{L}_3 = {{params.l3}} {{params.unitsDist}}, $ \mathbf{L}_4 = {{params.l4}} {{params.unitsDist}},and radious $ \mathbf{R} = {{params.radious}} {{params.unitsDist}}
solution.html:
First compute the reaction forces at points A and D by $ \Sigma F_x = 0 $, $ \Sigma F_y = 0 $ and $ \Sigma M_A = 0 $ of the whole system. Break up the system into 4 seprate parts. Beam AD,BF,CE, and pully F, and right the X and Y reaction forces acting at each point on all 4 parts.
    Solving reaction forces:
  • $ \Sigma F_x = 0, \implies A_x + D_x = 0, \implies A_x = -D_x$
  • $ \Sigma F_y = 0, \implies A_y - W = 0, \implies A_y = W, \implies A_y = {{params.W}} {{params.unitsForce}}$
  • $ \Sigma M_A = 0, \implies (D_x)(L_1+L_2+L_3+L_4) - (W)(L_1+L_2+r) = 0.$ Solving for $D_x = (W)(L_1+L_2+r) / (L_1+L_2+L_3+L_4) = {{correct_answers.DX}}$ ${{params.unitsForce}}$
    Reminder: If 2 parts share 1 point then the reactions on each parts must be equal oppisite to each other.
  • Example: when writing the reaction forces on beam AD.
  • Point A $\implies$ 2 reaction forces pointing right and up, (positve x direction) and (positive y direction).
  • Point B $\implies$ 2 reaction forces pointing right and up, (positve x direction) and (positive y direction).
  • Point C $\implies$ 2 reaction forces pointing right and up, (positve x direction) and (positive y direction).
  • Point D $\implies$ 1 reaction forces pointing right and up, (positve x direction).
  • There will also be a tension force pointing to the right, (positive x direction)
    • -
  • Example: when writing the reaction forces on beam CE.
  • Point C $\implies$ 2 reaction forces pointing left and down, (negative x direction) and (negative y direction).
  • Point E $\implies$ 2 reaction forces pointing right and up, (positive x direction) and (positive y direction).
    • -
  • Example: when writing the reaction forces on beam BF.
  • Point B $\implies$ 2 reaction forces pointing left and down, (negative x direction) and (negative y direction).
  • Point E $\implies$ 2 reaction forces pointing left and down, (negative x direction) and (negative y direction).
  • Point F $\implies$ 2 reaction forces pointing left and down, (negative x direction) and (negative y direction).
    • -
  • Example: when writing the reaction forces on pully F.
  • Point F $\implies$ 2 reaction forces pointing right and up, (positive x direction) and (positive y direction).
  • There will also be a 2 tension forces pointing left and down.
    • -
  • Now that everything is set up you can now start solving each part by doing $ \Sigma F_x = 0 $, $ \Sigma F_y = 0 $ and $ \Sigma M_A = 0. $
    Solving reaction forces:
  • Beam BF: $ \Sigma M_B = 0 \implies -(E_y)(L_2) - (W)(L_2+L_3+r)=0 \implies |E_y| = (W)(L_2+L_3+r)/-l_2 = {{correct_answers.DX}}$ ${{params.unitsForce}}$
    • -
  • Beam CE: tan($\theta$) = (opp/adj) $\implies$ tan($\theta$) =$ (L_1/L_2) \implies \theta = $atan$(L_1/L_2)$
  • Now we can solve for $E_x$: tan($\theta$) = $ E_y/E_x \implies |E_x| = E_y /$ tan($\theta$) = ${{correct_answers.EY}}$ ${{params.unitsForce}}$
  • By $ \Sigma F_x = 0 $, $ \Sigma F_y = 0 $ we can come to the conclusion that $C_x = E_x$ and $C_y = E_y$
    • -
  • Pully F: $ \Sigma F_x = 0 $, $ \Sigma F_y = 0 $ we can come to the conclusion that $F_y = W $ and $ F_x = W $
    • -
  • Beam BF: Now that we have $F_x,F_y,E_x,E_y$ we can solve for the reactions at point B.
  • $ \Sigma F_x = 0 $, $ \Sigma F_y = 0 \implies B_x = E_x - F_x,$ and $ B_y = E_y - F_y$
  • $B_x = {{correct_answers.BX}}$ {{params.unitsForce}}
  • $B_y = {{correct_answers.BY}}$ {{params.unitsForce}}
    • -
  • Note: The solutions want the magnitude of the forces which is why they all come out positve.
  • When you get negative solutions for reaction forces, that indactes that you have to switch the force direction.
  • For example: This is why when solving for $B_x$ it NOT $B_x = E_x + F_x$ even though that is technically correct with the way we initially drew the forces.
  • It is beacuse the true direction of $E_x$ on beam BF is to the right (positive x direction) regardless of the direction of our initial guess.

the frame supports the load $ \mathbf{w} = 500 n$. 
 neglecting the weights of the members and compute the magnitude of the horizontal and verticle components of all forces acting at points a,b,c,d,e,and f. 
 let the lengths $ \mathbf{l}_1 = 2 m $, $ \mathbf{l}_2 = 3 m$, $ \mathbf{l}_3 = 4 m$, $ \mathbf{l}_4 = 5 m$,and radious $ \mathbf{r} = 1 m$
title: Frames and machines

question.html:
A pair of forces (F) is applied to the eyelet squeezer. The green block at A is able to slide back and forth with negligible friction.

Compute the compressive force acting on the orange eyelet as a result of the two forces in {{params.unitsForce}}

let the force $ \mathbf(F) = {{params.force}} {{params.unitsForce}}$ and lengths $ \mathbf{L}_1 = {{params.length1}} {{params.unitsDist}}$, $ \mathbf{L}_2 = {{params.length2}} {{params.unitsDist}}$, $ \mathbf{L}_3 = {{params.length3}} {{params.unitsDist}}$ and $ \mathbf{L}_4 = {{params.length4}} {{params.unitsDist}}$
solution.html:
Break up the system into 4 parts and draw the reaction forces acting on each part. Try to solve for the reaction forece acting on point B
    Solving for the reaction forec at B: Using the free body diagram on member AC
  • $\Sigma M_A = 0, \implies B_r$ Sin($\theta$) $\sqrt{L_1^{2}+L_3^{2}}$ - $F(L_1+L_2)$ = 0
  • solving for $B_r$ we get $B_r = \frac{F(L_1+L_2)} {Sin(\theta)\sqrt{L_1^{2}+L_3^{2}} }$
  • Where $\theta$ = atan($\frac{L_3}{L_1}$) + atan($\frac{L_3+L_4}{L_2}$)
    • Now that we have the reaction froce at B, try and find the compressive force.
    Solving for the compressive force: Using the free body diagram on member AC
  • $\Sigma F_x = 0 \implies -A_x + B_r$ Cos($\phi$) = 0
  • $A_x$ =$ B_r$ Cos($\phi$)
  • Where $\phi$ = atan($\frac{L_3+L_4}{L_2}$)
  • Drawing the free body diagram for the dark green part and doing $\Sigma F_x = 0 \implies A_x -$CompressiveForce = 0
  • Compressive force = $A_x$
question: Refer to the diagram labeled "squeezer.png".  A pair of forces (F) is applied to the eyelet squeezer. The green block at point A is able to slide back and forth with negligible friction.  Compute the compressive force acting on the orange eyelet as a result of the two forces.  Given:  Force,   = 100 F=100 N (for example) Lengths:  1 = 2 L  1   =2 m (for example)  2 = 1.5 L  2   =1.5 m (for example)  3 = 3 L  3   =3 m (for example)  4 = 2.5 L  4   =2.5 m (for example) Determine:  Compressive force on the orange eyelet.
title: Frames and machines squeezer

question.html:
Determine the reaction forces at points A and B under the force $ \mathbf{P} = {{params.forceP}} {{params.unitsForce}} $and distributed force $ \mathbf{F}_D = {{params.forceD}} {{params.unitsForcee}}$.

Let the lengths $ \mathbf{L}_1 = {{params.length1}} {{params.unitsDist}}$ and $ \mathbf{L}_2 = {{params.length2}} {{params.unitsDist}}$
solution.html:
Draw the freebody diagram. Then write out the equations for $ \Sigma F_x = 0 $, $ \Sigma F_y = 0 $ and $ \Sigma M_A = 0 $. You could also take sum of moments about point B. Replace the distributed force by a concentrated force acting at the centroid of the distributed force
  • $ \Sigma F_x = 0 \implies A_x = 0 $
  • Replace the distributed force by a concentrated force.
  • $ \Sigma F_y = 0 \implies A_y + B_y - {{params.forceP}} - ({{params.forceD}})({{params.length1}}) = 0 $
  • $ \Sigma M_A = 0 \implies B_y ({{params.length1}}+ {{params.length2}}) - ({{params.forceP}})({{params.length1}}) - ({{params.forceD}})({{params.length1}})({{params.length1}} + {{params.length2}} + {{params.length1}}/2) = 0 $
  • Solve the moment equation for $ B_y $ to obtain $ B_y = {{correct_answers.reactionBy}} {{params.unitsForce}} $
  • Substitute in the equation for the vertical force balance to obtain $ A_y = {{correct_answers.reactionAy}} {{params.unitsForce}} $
question:
determine the reaction forces at points a and b under the force $ \mathbf{p} = 500 n $ and distributed force $ \mathbf{f}_d = 1000 n/m$. 
let the lengths $ \mathbf{l}_1 = 2 meters$ and $ \mathbf{l}_2 = 3 meters$
title: Distributed forces
topics: Reaction Forces, Distributed Forces, Static Equilibrium

question.html:
Determine the reaction forces at points A and B under the force $ \mathbf{F} = {{params.force}} {{params.unitsForce}}$ and the distributed forces $ \mathbf{P}_D = {{params.forceP}} {{params.unitsForcee}}$ and $ \mathbf{F}_D = {{params.forceD}} {{params.unitsForcee}}$ .

Let the lengths $ \mathbf{L}_1 = {{params.length1}} {{params.unitsDist}}$, $ \mathbf{L}_2 = {{params.length2}} {{params.unitsDist}}$ and $ \mathbf{L}_3 = {{params.length3}} {{params.unitsDist}}$.
solution.html:
Draw the freebody diagram. Then write out the equations for $ \Sigma F_x = 0 $, $ \Sigma F_y = 0 $ and $ \Sigma M_A = 0 $. You could also take sum of moments about point A. Replace the distributed force by a single concentrated force acting at the centroid of the distributed force
  • By doing $ \Sigma F_x = 0 \implies A_x = 0 $
  • Replace the distributed force by a single concentrated force.
  • $ \Sigma M_A = 0 \implies B_y ({{params.length3}}+ {{params.length1}}) - ({{params.forceD}})({{params.length1}})({{params.length3}}+ {{params.length1}}/2) + ({{params.forceP}})({{params.length2}})({{params.length3}}+ {{params.length2}}/2)+ ({{params.force}})({{params.length3}}+ {{params.length1}}+ {{params.length3}})= 0 $
  • By doing $ \Sigma F_y = 0 \implies A_y + B_y + {{params.force}} - ({{params.forceD}})({{params.length1}}) - ({{params.forceP}})({{params.length2}}) = 0 $
  • Solve the moment equation for $ B_y $ to obtain $ B_y = {{correct_answers.reactionBy}} {{params.unitsForce}} $
  • Substitute $ B_y $ and solve for $ A_y $ in the $ \Sigma F_y = 0 $ equation to obtain $ A_y = {{correct_answers.reactionAy}} {{params.unitsForce}} $
question:
determine the reaction forces at points a and b under the force $ \mathbf{f} = 100 n$ and the distributed forces $ \mathbf{p}_d = 50 n/m$ and $ \mathbf{f}_d = 20 n/m$ . 
let the lengths $ \mathbf{l}_1 = 2 m$, $ \mathbf{l}_2 = 3 m$ and $ \mathbf{l}_3 = 4 m$.
title: Distributed forces
topics: Reaction Forces, Distributed Forces, Static Equilibrium

question.html:
Determine the magnitude of the resultant forces and there distance from point A. Then compute the moment about point A in ${{params.unitsForce}}$-${{params.unitsDist}}$

Let the distributed forces $ \mathbf{F}_D = {{params.forceF}} {{params.unitsForcee}}$ and $ \mathbf{P}_D = {{params.forceP}} {{params.unitsForcee}}$

Let the lengths $ \mathbf{L}_1 = {{params.length1}} {{params.unitsDist}}$ and $ \mathbf{L}_2 = {{params.length2}} {{params.unitsDist}}$
solution.html:
Break both of the distributed forces down and create two single concentrated forces acting at there centroids. By creating to concentrated forces as a result of the two distributed forces, you should have force F pointing down and force P pointing up.
  • To find the magnitude of the forces compute the area of the triangular shape by using the height: $ F_D $ and $ P_D $ and lengths: $ L_1 $ and $ L_2 $
  • Concentrated force $ F = ({{params.forceF}})({{params.length1}})/2$ and concentrated force $ P = ({{params.forceP}})({{params.length2}})/2 $.
  • To find the location of the concentrated forces you must find the centroid of the distributed forces and compute there distances from point A. Since both of the distributed forces are triangular shaped we know the centroid of a triangle is 1/3 the base with an orgin at the right angle.
  • Position of concentrated forces relative to point A: $ F_x = ({{params.length1}})(2/3) $ and $P_x = ({{params.length2}})(1/3) + {{params.length1}}$
  • With the the two concentrated forces and the positions, you can now calculate the moment about point A.
  • To calculate the moment about point A we must multiply the forces acting on the beam by the distances it is from point A.
  • Moment about point A = -(F)($F_x$)+(P)($P_x$), Which will come out to ${{correct_answers.momentA}}\ {{params.unitsForce}}{{params.unitsDist}}$
question: Refer to the diagram labeled "distributedForces3.png".  Determine the magnitude of the resultant forces and their distance from point A. Then compute the moment about point A in N-m.  Given:  Distributed forces: FD = 200 N PD = 150 N Lengths: L1 = 3 m L2 = 2 m Determine:  Resultant force F Resultant force P Distance F from point A Distance P from point A Moment about point A
title: Distributed forces

question.html:
Compute the moment about point A in ${{params.unitsForce}}$-${{params.unitsDist}}$

Let the path of the distributed force be modeled as the function w(x), $ \mathbf{F}_D = {{params.forceF}} {{params.unitsForcee}}$

Let the length $ \mathbf{L}_1 = {{params.length1}} {{params.unitsDist}}$ and Let $ \mathbf{k} = {{params.constant}}$.
solution.html:
Break down the distributed force to one single concentrated force. Place The concentrated force at the centroid of the function.
  • To compute the concentrated force you must take the integral of the function modeling the distributed force.
  • when computing the integral from 0 to ${{params.length1}}$ of w(x) you should get F= $({{params.constant}})({{params.length1}})^4/4$
  • To compute the centroid of the function it is simply the integral of (x)(w(x)) divided by the force or the integral of w(x).
  • when computing the integral from 0 to ${{params.length1}}$ of (x)(w(x)) you should get $({{params.constant}})({{params.length1}})^5/5$. Dividing this by the force you should get $ 4/5({{params.length1}})$.
  • To calculate the moment about point A we must multiply the force acting on the beam by the distance it is from point A.
  • When computing the moment about A you should get, $M_A= (F)(Distance) = ((({{params.constant}})({{params.length1}})^4)/4)( 4/5({{params.length1}})) = {{correct_answers.momentA}}\ {{params.unitsForce}}{{params.unitsDist}}$
question: Refer to the diagram labeled "distributedForces4.png".  Compute the moment about point A in N-m.  Given:  Path of the distributed force modeled as the function w(x): FD = 300 N Length: L1 = 4 m Constant: k = 5 (for example) Determine:  Moment about point A
title: Distributed forces

question.html:
Determine the reaction force at point B so that the moment about A is balanced out to zero.

Let the lengths $ \mathbf{L}_1 = {{params.length1}} {{params.unitsDist}}$, $ \mathbf{L}_2 = {{params.length2}} {{params.unitsDist}}$, $ \mathbf{L}_3 = {{params.length3}} {{params.unitsDist}}$ and let the distributed force $ \mathbf{F}_D={{params.forceD}} {{params.unitsForcee}}$

Note: The Green distributed force is modeled by the function w(x), where (w= weight and x= distance) and the red distribted force is a quarter cirlce.
solution.html:
Break down the 4 distributed forces to 4 single concentrated forces. Place the 4 concentrated forces at there centroids.
  • To convert the distributed force in green into a concentrated force you must take the intagrel of the function w(x).
  • To convert the other 3 distributed forces to 3 concentrated forces you must compute the areas of the shapes by using the given lengths and the (distributed force per unit length) as the heights.
  • To compute the centroid of the distributed force in green we must simply take the integral of (x)(w(x)) divided by the force or the integral of w(x).
  • To compute the centroids of the other 3 shapes we must know the following information: centroid of a quarter circle = (4)(r)/(3$\pi$), Triangle = 1/3(Base) , Square= (Base)/2
  • Green distributed load into a concentrated force: $F_G$ = integral from 0 to ${{params.length1}}$ of w(x) = $(({{params.constant}})({{params.length2}})^3)/3.$
  • Red distributed load into concentrated force: $F_R$ = $\pi(w({{params.length1}})^2)/4$.
  • Purple distributed load into a concentrated force: $F_P$ = $ ({{params.forceD}})({{params.length1}})/2$
  • Orange distributed load into a concentrated force: $F_O$ = $({{params.forceD}})({{params.length1}})$
  • Green centroid position: $G_x$ = integral from 0 to ${{params.length1}}$ of w(x)(x) devided by the $F_G$ = $(({{params.constant}})({{params.length2}})^4/4) / (({{params.constant}})({{params.length2}})^3/3) = (3/4)({{params.length1}})$
  • Red centroid position: $R_x = (4)(2)({{params.length3}})/3\pi$
  • Purple centroid position: $P_x = (1/3)({{params.length1}})$
  • Orange centroid position: $O_x = {{params.length3}}/2$
    Now that we have all 4 of the concentrated forces and there centroid positions, we can now take the moment about point A to solve for reaction force at point B ($B_y$). $ \Sigma M_A = 0 \implies B_y(L_1+L_2) + F_G(L_3+L_2-G_x) + F_R(L_3-R_x) - F_P(L_3+L_1-P_x) - F_O(L_1+L_3+L_3-O_x) = 0 .$ Now you can solve for $B_y$ to obtain a solution of $B_y = {{correct_answers.reactionB}}\ {{params.unitsForce}}$

  • Note: The solutions want the magnitude of the forces which is why they all come out positve.
  • When you get negative solutions for reaction forces, that indactes that you have to switch the force direction.
  • For example: This is why when solving for $B_x$ it NOT $B_x = E_x + F_x$ even though that is technically correct with the way we initially drew the forces.
  • It is beacuse the true direction of $E_x$ on beam BF is to the right (positive x direction) regardless of the direction of our initial guess.

question.html:
The two ropes hold up the orange sign of weight ${{params.w}}$ ${{params.unitsForce}}$

Neglect the weight of the blue beam that connects points A and B. Let the length $\mathbf{L}_1 = {{params.L}}$ $ {{params.unitsDist}}$.

Compute the tension in ropes BD and BC, also compute the reaction forces action on the ball joint A.
solution.html:
First, define the tension in cable BD and BC as a vector expression. You can do this by multiplying the tension in the cables by the according unit vector of the cable, starting from point B. At this point, we don't know the tension in the cable so we can just call the tension in cable BD $\mathbf{T}_1$ and the tension in the cable BC $\mathbf{T}_2$.

Let the unit vector for cable BD be $\frac{-2L_1 \hat{i}-2L_1\hat{j}+L_1\hat{z}}{\sqrt{2L_1^2+2L_1^2+L_1^2}}$ and the unit vector for BC be $\frac{L_1\hat{i}-2L_1\hat{j}+2L_1\hat{z}}{\sqrt{L_1^2+2L_1^2+2L_1^2}}$.

So that the vector expression for $ T_1$ is $\vec{T}_1 = (T_1) \frac{-2L_1 \hat{i}-2L_1\hat{j}+L_1\hat{z}}{\sqrt{2L_1^2+2L_1^2+L_1^2}}$ and the vector expression for $T_2$ is $ \vec{T}_2 = (T_1) \frac{L_1\hat{i}-2L_1\hat{j}+2L_1\hat{z}}{\sqrt{L_1^2+2L_1^2+2L_1^2}}$.
    Now that we set up our tensions in terms of vectors we can start solving.

    Let's start with summing up the forces in all directions.

  • $\Sigma{F}_x = 0 \implies Ax+\vec{T}_1\hat{i}+\vec{T}_2\hat{i}=0 $
  • $\Sigma{F}_y = 0 \implies Ay+\vec{T}_1\hat{j}+\vec{T}_2\hat{j}=0 $
  • $\Sigma{F}_z = 0 \implies Az+\vec{T}_1\hat{k}+\vec{T}_2\hat{k}-W = 0$
    • Where Ax, Ay, and Az are the reaction forces at point A.

    We also need to take the moment about point A to acquire 4 equations to solve for all the unknowns.

    let the vector $\vec{d}_a$ be the vector that describes the distance from point A to point B. ie $\vec{d}_a = 0\hat{i}+2L_1\hat{j}+0\hat{k}$

    And let the vector $\vec{d}_w$ be the vector from point A to halfway to point B where the weight vector lies. ie $\vec{d}_w = 0\hat{i}+L_1\hat{j}+0\hat{k}$

  • $\Sigma{M}_A = 0 \implies \vec{d}_a $ X $ \vec{T}_1+ \vec{d}_a $ X $ \vec{T}_2 + \vec{d}_w $ X $ \vec{W} = 0$
    • Now you can solve all of the cross-products to acquire $T_1$ and $T_2$. And use the tension to solve for Ax, Ay, and Az.
    When solving all of the cross-products we get:
  • $\vec{d}_a X \vec{T}_1 = (2L_1)(\vec{T}_1\hat{k}) \hat{i} - (0)\hat{j} + (-2L_1)(\vec{T}_1\hat{i})\hat{k}$
  • $\vec{d}_a X \vec{T}_2 = (2L_1)(\vec{T}_2\hat{k}) \hat{i} - (0)\hat{j} + (-2L_1)(\vec{T}_2\hat{i})\hat{k}$
  • $\vec{d}_w X \vec{W} = (-W)(L_1)\hat{i} + 0 \hat{j} + 0 \hat{k}$

    • We can set all of the $\hat{i}$'s = 0, $\hat{j}$'s = 0 ,and $\hat{k}$'s = 0 to solve for tension.

  • $\hat{i}$ : $(2L_1)(\vec{T}_1\hat{k}) + (2L_1)(\vec{T}_2\hat{k}) - (W)(L_1) = 0$
  • $\hat{j}$ : 0 = 0
  • $\hat{k}$ : $(-2L_1)(T_1\hat{i})+(-2L_1)(T_2\hat{i})$ = 0

    • Solving the system of equations we get: $\mathbf{T}_1 = {{corect_answers.T1}} {{params.unitsForce}}$ and $\mathbf{T}_2 = {{corect_answers.T2}} {{params.unitsForce}}$.

    Now that we have our tensions, we can solve for Ax, Ay, and Az using the force equations from earlier.
    Using the force equations and our tensions we are able to solve the reaction forces at point A.

    $A_x = {{correct_answers.Ax}}{{params.unitsForce}}

    $A_y = {{correct_answers.Ay}}{{params.unitsForce}}

    $A_z = {{correct_answers.Az}}{{params.unitsForce}}

question.html:
The structure is welded to the ground and is in stress from the forces $\mathbf{F}_G = {{params.fg}}$ ${{params.unitsForce}}$, $\mathbf{F}_R = {{params.fr}}$ ${{params.unitsForce}}$, and $ \mathbf{F}_P = {{params.fp}} $ ${{params.unitsForce}}$

Let the lengths $ \mathbf{L}_1 = {{params.l1}}{{params.unitsDist}}$, $\mathbf{L}_2 = {{params.l2}}$ ${{params.unitsDist}}$, and $\mathbf{L}_3 = {{params.l3}}$ ${{params.unitsDist}}$

Compute the reaction forces at point A.

Note:The direction of the force matters when submitting your final answer. Denote clockwise rotation as negative (-) and conter clockwise as positive(+).
solution.html:
First, draw the reaction force at point A.

The reaction forces at point A should have 6 components.

$A_x, A_y, A_z, $ and $M_x, M_y, M_z$.

Now write out the equations that describe the forces in all directions.
    Equations that discribe all of the forces:
  • $\Sigma{F}_x = 0 \implies A_x-F_P =0$
  • $\Sigma{F}_y = 0 \implies A_y+F_R =0$
  • $\Sigma{F}_z = 0 \implies A_z-F_G =0$
    • Moment equations (about point A):
  • $\Sigma{M}_x = 0 \implies M_x-(L_3+L_2)(F_R)-(L_1)(F_G) =0$
  • $\Sigma{M}_y = 0 \implies M_y-(L_2)(F_P)-(L_2)(F_G) =0$
  • $\Sigma{M}_z = 0 \implies M_z =0$
    • With all of these equations you are able to solve for all of the reaction forces at point A.
    Reaction forces at point A:
  • $A_x = {{correct_answers.Ax}} {{params.unitsForce}}
  • $A_y = {{correct_answers.Ay}} {{params.unitsForce}}
  • $A_z = {{correct_answers.Az}} {{params.unitsForce}}
  • $M_x = {{correct_answers.Mx}} {{params.unitsForce}} {{params.unitsDist}}
  • $M_y = {{correct_answers.My}} {{params.unitsForce}} {{params.unitsDist}}
  • $M_z = {{correct_answers.Mz}} {{params.unitsForce}} {{params.unitsDist}}

question.html:
Compute the reaction forces acting on the smooth bearings at points A,B,and C.

Let the forces $\mathbf{F}_R = {{params.fr}} {{params.unitsForce}}$, $\mathbf{F}_G = {{params.fg}} {{params.unitsForce}}$, $\mathbf{F}_P = {{params.fp}} {{params.unitsForce}}$,and $\mathbf{F}_B = {{params.fb}} {{params.unitsForce}}$

Let the lenghths $ \mathbf{L}_1 = {{params.l1}} {{params.unitsDist}}$, and $ \mathbf{L}_2 = {{params.l2}} {{params.unitsDist}}$
solution.html:
First, draw all of the reaction forces acting on all of the bearings.

The reaction force on bearing A should be $A_x$ and $A_z$

The reaction forces on bearing B should be $B_x$ and $B_z$

The reaction forces on bearing C should be $C_y$ and $C_z$

Now write out the equations that discribe the force in all directions and moments in all directions.
    Equations that discribe all of the forces:
  • $\Sigma{F}_x = 0 \implies A_x + B_x -F_R = 0$
  • $\Sigma{F}_y = 0 \implies C_y - F_G =0$
  • $\Sigma{F}_z = 0 \implies A_z + B_z + C_z - F_B -F_P =0$
    • Moment equations (about point A):
  • $\Sigma{M}_x = 0 \implies (B_z)(L_1+L_1)+(C_z)(L_1+L_1+L_1)+(F_G)(L_2)-(F_P)(L_1+L_1+L_1)-(F_B)(L_1)=0$
  • $\Sigma{M}_y = 0 \implies (C_z)(L_1+L_1)-(F_P)(L_1)+(F_B)(L_2) =0$
  • $\Sigma{M}_z = 0 \implies (F_R)(L_1)-(B_x)(L_1+L_1)+(F_G)(L_1)-(C_y)(L_1+L_1)=0$
    • Now you have 6 equations and 6 unknowns. Now we can solve for everthing.
    First we can use $\Sigma{M}_y$ equation to solve for $C_z$
  • $C_z = {{correct_answers.Cz}}$
    • Now we can use $\Sigma{M}_x$ and $\Sigma{M}_z$ equations to solve for $B_z$ and $B_x$.
  • $B_z = {{correct_answers.Bz}}$
  • $B_x = {{correct_answers.Bx}}$
    • Using $C_z,B_x,$ and $B_z$ we can solve for A_x and A_z using $\Sigma{F}_x$ and $\Sigma{F}_z$ equations.
  • $A_x = {{correct_answers.Ax}}$
  • $A_z = {{correct_answers.Az}}$
    • Lastly we can use the $\Sigma{F}_y$ equation to find $C_z$
  • $C_y = {{correct_answers.Cy}}$
    • Any other force equals zero.

question.html:
The member is supported by a pin at A and the cable BC.

The load is $ \mathbf{W} = {{params.weight}} {{params.unitsForce}}$, and the lengths are $ \mathbf{L}_1 = {{params.l1}}$, $ \mathbf{L}_2 = {{params.l2}}$, and $ \mathbf{L}_3 = {{params.l3}} {{params.unitsDist}}$.

Compute the reaction forces at pin A and the tension in the cable.

Note: Pin A is constrained, so it cannot freely slide in the x-direction but it is able to rotate about the x-axis.
solution.html:
First draw the reaction forces at point A.

The reaction forces at point A should be $A_x, A_y,A_z,M_y,M_z$.

Next we have to describe the tension in the cable as a vector.

We can do this by multiplying the the magnitude of the tension with the unit vector that matches the path of the cable.
    Finding the tesnion vector $\vec{T}$. First we must identify the unit vector that matches the path of the cable.
  • $\vec{U} = \frac{(L_2+L_2-L_1)\hat{i}-L_3\hat{j}+L_2\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(L_2+L_2-L_1)^2+(L_3)^2+(L_2)^2}}$
  • So the vector expression for the tesnion is simply $\vec{T} = (T)(\vec{U}) = (T)(\frac{(L_2+L_2-L_1)\hat{i}-L_3\hat{j}+L_2\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(L_2+L_2-L_1)^2+(L_3)^2+(L_2)^2}})$
    • Since we do not know what tesnion is yet we can just leave T in $\vec{T}$ for now. set up the equations that discribe all of the forces in the system. We will also need to take the moment about point A for an additional equation.
  • $\Sigma{F}_x = 0 \implies A_x + \vec{T}\hat{i} = 0$
  • $\Sigma{F}_y = 0 \implies A_y + \vec{T}\hat{j} = 0$
  • $\Sigma{F}_z = 0 \implies A_z + \vec{T}\hat{k} - W = 0$
    • Moment equations (about point A):

    But before we set up our three moment equations we first have to compute $\vec{d} X \vec{T}$.

    Where $\vec{d} = -2L_2\hat{i}+L_3\hat{j}+0\hat{k}$ goes from point A to the end of the cable.

  • $\vec{d} X \vec{T} = (L_3)(\vec{T}\hat{k})\hat{i}-(-2L_2)(\vec{T}\hat{k})\hat{j}+(-2L_2)(\vec{T}\hat{j})-(L_3)(\vec{T}\hat{i})\hat{k}$
    • setting up moment equations(about point A):
  • $\Sigma{M}_x = 0 \implies (L_3)(\vec{T}\hat{k})-(W)(L_3) = 0$
    • ;
  • $\Sigma{M}_y = 0 \implies -(-2L_2)(\vec{T}\hat{k})-(W)(L_2)+M_y= 0$
    • ;
  • $\Sigma{M}_z = 0 \implies M_z + (-2L_2)(\vec{T}\hat{j})-(L_3)(\vec{T}\hat{i})= 0$
    • ;

    Note: $\Sigma{M}_x$ does not have a moment reaction force since the structure can freely rotate about the x-axis.

  • So, $M_x = 0$
    • Now you have 6 unknowns and 6 equation. Now you can solve.

    Solving the $\Sigma{M}_x$ we are able to solve for tension.

  • T = ${{correct.answers.T}} {{params.unitForce}} $

    • Now that we have tension, we can solve for $M_y$ and $M_z$ using the $\Sigma{M}_y$ and $\Sigma{M}_z$ equations.

  • $M_y ={{correct.answers.My}} {{params.unitForce}} {{params.unitsDist}}$
  • $M_z ={{correct.answers.Mz}} {{params.unitForce}} {{params.unitsDist}}$

    • Lastly we are easily able to solve for $A_x,A_y,$ and $A_z$ using the force equations.

  • $Ax ={{correct.answers.Ax}} {{params.unitForce}} $
  • $Ay ={{correct.answers.Ay}} {{params.unitForce}} $
  • $Az ={{correct.answers.Az}} {{params.unitForce}} $

the member is supported by a pin at a and the cable bc.

question.html:
The brace DC holds up the orange plate that has a weight of $\mathbf{W} = {{params.weight}}{{params.unitsForce}}$

Compute the tension in brace DC and the magnitude of the reaction forces acting on hinges A and B.

let the lengths $\mathbf{L}_1 = {{params.l1}}$, $\mathbf{L}_2 = {{params.l2}}$, and $\mathbf{L}_3 = {{params.l3}} {{params.unitsDist}}$.

Note: The hing at point A does not exert any axial thrust.
solution.html:
First draw the reaction force at Points B and A. The reactions at point B should be $B_x,B_y$ and,$B_z$. And the reactions at point A should be $A_z$ and $A_y$
    Now that we identified the reaction forces we can now start to solve the problem.

    First, we want to represent the tension in the beam as a vector.

    We can do this by simply multiplying the tension force by the unit vector that follows the same path as the beam.

    So, let the unit vector goes from point D to C be $\vec{U} = \frac{L_3\hat{i}+L_2\hat{j}+L_1\hat{k}}{\sqrt{(L_3)^2+(L_2)^2+(L_1)^2}}$

    Now that we have the unit vector we can say the tension vector is:

  • $\vec{T} = (T)\vec{U} = (T)\frac{L_3\hat{i}+L_2\hat{j}+L_1\hat{k}}{\sqrt{L_3^2+L_2^2+L_1^2}}$.

    • Now that we have the tension vector the next step is to write out our equations that will help us solve for the reactions and tens{{params.}} {{params.unitsForce}}ion force.

    Write out the equations of force and moments in all directions.

    Equations of force:

  • $\Sigma{F}_x = 0 \implies A_x +B_x + \vec{T}\hat{i} =0$
  • $\Sigma{F}_y = 0 \implies A_y +B_y + \vec{T}\hat{j} - W =0$
  • $\Sigma{F}_z = 0 \implies B_z + \vec{T}\hat{k} =0$
    • Moment equations (about point B):

    But before we set up our three moment equations we first have to compute $\vec{d} X \vec{T}$.

    Where $\vec{d} = 0\hat{i}-L_2\hat{j}+L_1\hat{k}$ goes from point B to point D.

  • $\vec{d} X \vec{T} = (-L_2)(\vec{T}\hat{k})-(L_1)(\vec{T}\hat{j})hat{i}-(L_1)(\vec{T}\hat{i})\hat{j}+(L_2)(\vec{T}\hat{i})\hat{k}$

    • Now we can set up our moment equations about each axis:

  • $\Sigma{M}_x = 0 \implies (-2L_1)(A_y)+(W)(L_1)+(-L_2)(\vec{T}\hat{k})-(L_1)(\vec{T}\hat{j}) = 0$
  • $\Sigma{M}_y = 0 \implies (2L_1)(A_x)+(L_1)(\vec{T}\hat{i})= 0$
  • $\Sigma{M}_z = 0 \implies (L_2)(\vec{T}\hat{i})-(W)(\frac{L_3}{2})= 0$
    • Now you have 6 unknowns and 6 equation. Now you can solve.
    Solving equations:

    Using the $\Sigma{M}_z$ equation, we are able to solve for tension.

  • $T = {{params.T}} {{params.unitsForce}}$

    • Now that we have tension we can use equations $\Sigma{M}_x$ and $\Sigma{M}_y$ to solve for $A_x$ and $A_y$.

  • $A_x ={{params.Ax}} {{params.unitsForce}} $
  • $A_y ={{params.Ay}} {{params.unitsForce}} $

    • Now using the information we have now we can use the force equations to solve for $B_x,B_y$ and $B_z$.

  • $B_x ={{params.Bx}} {{params.unitsForce}} $
  • $B_y ={{params.By}} {{params.unitsForce}} $
  • $B_z ={{params.Bz}} {{params.unitsForce}} $

question:
compute the magnitude of the reaction forces at joints a and e.

question.html:
A 450-lb load hangs from the corner $C$ of a rigid piece of pipe $ABCD$ that has been bent as shown. The pipe is supported by ball-and-socket joints $A$ and $D$, and by a cable attached at the midpoint $E$ of the portion $BC$ of the pipe and at point $G$ on the wall. Determine (a) where $G$ should be located if the tension in the cable is to be minimum, (b) the corresponding minimum value of tension.

The x-coordinate of the location of G ($G_X$) is equal to:

The y-coordinate of the location of G ($G_Y$) is equal to:

The minimum value of tension ($T_{min}$) is equal to:
solution.html:
Draw the free-body diagram of the pipe showing the reactions at $A$ and $D$. Isolate the unknown tension $T$ and the known weight $W$ by summing moments about the diagonal line $AD$, and compute values from the equilibrium equations. The vector expression of line AB $\overline{AB}$ $\implies$ $\hat{r_{BC}} = [(12\hat{i} + 12\hat{j} - 6\hat{k})]/[\sqrt(18)]$ = ($\frac{2}{3}\hat{i} + \frac{2}{3}\hat{j} + -\frac{1}{3}\hat{k}$)
  • $\implies \overrightarrow{AC} \times W = (12\hat{i} + 12\hat{j}) \times (-450j) = -5400k$
  • $\hat{r_{BC}} \cdot (\overrightarrow{AC} \times W) = (\frac{2}{3}\hat{i} + \frac{2}{3}\hat{j} + -\frac{1}{3}\hat{k}) \cdot (-5400k) = +1800 $ $\textbf{(2)}$

Recalling the commutative property for mixed triple products, you can rewrite the last equation in the form

  • $T \cdot (\hat{r_{BC}} \times \overrightarrow{AE}) = -1800 lb \cdot ft$ $\textbf{(3)}$
  • This shows that the projection of $T$ on the vector $\hat{r_{BC}} \times \overrightarrow{AE}$ is a constant. It follows that $T$ is minimum when it is parallel to the vector
  • $\implies \hat{r_{BC}} \times \overrightarrow{AE} = (\frac{2}{3}\hat{i} + \frac{2}{3}\hat{j} + -\frac{1}{3}\hat{k}) \times (6i + 12j) = 4i - 2j + 4k$
  • The corresponding unit vector is $(\frac{2}{3}i - \frac{1}{3} + \frac{2}{3}k)$ which yields
  • $\implies T_{min} = T(\frac{2}{3}i - \frac{1}{3} + \frac{2}{3}k)$ $\textbf{(4)}$
  • Substituting for $T$ and $\hat{r_{BC}}$ in Eq. (3) and computing dot products yields $T = -300$, carrying this value into Eq.(4)
  • $\implies T_{min} = 300 lb$
  • Since the vector $\overrightarrow{EG}$ and the force $T_{min}$ have the same direction, their components must be proportional.
  • Denoting the coordinates of G by x,y, and 0, you get
  • $\frac{x-6}{-200} = \frac{y-12}{+100} = \frac{0-6}{-200}$
  • $\implies x = 0, y = 15 ft

question.html:
Find the force acting on each of the three wheels $A, B, C$

The magnitude of the force acting at wheel A is:

The magnitude of the force acting at wheel B is:

The magnitude of the force acting at wheel C is:
solution.html:
3D equilibrium dictates $\Sigma F_x = 0$, $\Sigma F_y = 0$, $\Sigma F_z = 0$, $\Sigma M_{sum} = 0$. Deconstruct the given forces into their vector expressions and sketch the free body diagram with all moments/reactions. $*Note*$ The only external forces acting on the cart are vertical (in the z-direction), so it may be easiest to begin with the $\Sigma F_{z} = 0$ equation
  • $\Sigma F_{z} = 0 \implies A_{z} + B_{z} + C_{z} - 1600$ $Eq. \textbf{(1)}$
  • Although setting up the equation does not immediately solve for any unknowns, we can utilize the $\Sigma M = 0$ equations to find values to plug in
  • $\Sigma M_{X} = 0 \implies 800(5) + 300(15) + 500(27) - A_{z}(35) = 0$ $\textbf{(2)}$
  • $\implies A_{z} = 629$ lb

Repeat these steps using the moment equation for the y-axis ($\Sigma M_{Y} = 0$) and plug your values back into Eq. 1
  • $\Sigma M_{Y} = 0 \implies C_{z}(24) - 800(12) - 500(24) + 629(12) = 0$ $\textbf{(3)}$
  • $\implies C_{z} = 586$ lb
  • Plugging $A_{z}$ and $C_{z}$ back into Eq. 1 allow you to solve for $B_{z}$
  • $\implies B_{z} = 386$ lb

question.html:
A uniform pipe cover of radius $ r = 240 mm$ and mass $30 kg$ is held in a horizontal position by the cable $CD$. Assuming that the bearing at $B$ does not exert any axial thrust, determine the tension in the cable and the reactions at $A$ and $B$.

The magnitude of the tension in cable $CD$ ($T_{CD}$) is:

The x-component of the reaction at point A ($A_X$) is equal to:

The y-component of the reaction at point A ($A_Y$) is equal to:

The z-component of the reaction at point A ($A_Z$) is equal to:

The x-component of the reaction at point B ($B_X$) is equal to:

The y-component of the reaction at point B ($B_Y$) is equal to:

The z-component of the reaction at point B ($B_Z$) is equal to:
solution.html:
Draw a free-body diagram with the coordinate axes shown and express the unknown cable tension as a Cartesian vector. Then apply the equilibrium equations ($\Sigma F_{xyz} = 0$ and $\Sigma M_{xyz} = 0$ ) to determine this tension and the support reactions. The forces acting on the free body include its weight, which is
  • $W = -mg\hat{j} = (-294 N) \hat{j}$

Express the components of $\mathbf{T}$ in terms of the unknown magnitude T by resolving the vector $\overrightarrow{DC}$ into rectangular components:

  • $\overrightarrow{DC} = -(480 mm)\hat{i} + (240 mm)\hat{j} - (160 mm)\hat{k} \implies$ $DC$ = 560 mm
  • $\mathbf{T}$ = $T$$\frac{\overrightarrow{DC}}{DC}$ = $-\frac{6}{7}T\hat{i} + \frac{3}{7}T\hat{j} - \frac{2}{7}T\hat{k}$
  • Applying equilibirum conditions ($\Sigma F = 0$)
  • $ A_{x}\hat{i} + A_{y}\hat{j} + A_{z}\hat{k} + B_{x}\hat{i} + B_{y}\hat{j} + \mathbf{T} - (294 N)\hat{j}$
  • $(A_{x} + B_{x} - \frac{6}{7}T)\hat{i} + (A_{y} + B_{y} + \frac{3}{7}T - 294 N) \hat{j} + (A_{z} -\frac{2}{7}T)\hat{k} = 0$ $\textbf{(Eq. 1)}$

What equilibrium equation should you use next considering what forces are creating moments about points $A$ and $B$. Which equation will be easier to solve?
  • $\Sigma M_{B} = \Sigma(r \times F) = 0$:
  • $\implies 2r\hat{k} \times (A_{x}\hat{i} + A_{y}\hat{j} + A_{z}\hat{k}) + (2r\hat{i} + r\hat{k}) \times (-\frac{6}{7}T\hat{i} + \frac{3}{7}T\hat{j} - \frac{2}{7}T\hat{k}) + (r\hat{i} + r\hat{k}) \times (-294 N)\hat{j}$
  • $\implies (-2A_{y} - \frac{3}{7}T + 294 N)r\hat{i} + (2A_{x} - \frac{2}{7})r\hat{j} + (\frac{6}{7}T - 294 N)r\hat{k} $ $\textbf{(Eq. 2)}$
  • Setting the coefficients of the unit vectors equal to zero in Eq. 2 gives three scalar equations, which yield
  • $A_{x} = +49 N$
  • $A_{y} = +73.5 N$
  • $\implies T = 343 N$
  • Setting the coefficients of the unit vectors equal to zero in Eq. 1 produces three more scalar equations. After substituting the values of $T, A_{x},$ and $A_{y}$ into these equations you obtain:
  • $A_{z} = +98.0 N$
  • $B_{x} = +245 N$
  • $B_{y} = +73.5 N$
  • The reactions at $A$ and $B$ are therefore
  • $A = +(49 N)\hat{i} + (73.5)\hat{j} + (98 N)\hat{k}$
  • $B = +(245 N)\hat{i} + (73.5)\hat{j} + (0 N)\hat{k}$

question.html:
Determine the components of reaction at the ball-and-socket joint A and the tension in each cable necessary for equilibrium of the rod.

The x-component of the reaction force at A ($A_x$) is equal to:

The y-component of the reaction force at A ($A_y$) is equal to:

The z-component of the reaction force at A ($A_z$) is equal to:

The force of tension acting along cable BC ($T_{BC}$) is equal to:

The force of tension acting along cable BD ($T_{BD}$) is equal to:
solution.html:
3D equilibrium dictates $\Sigma F_x = 0$, $\Sigma F_y = 0$, $\Sigma F_z = 0$, $\Sigma M_{sum} = 0$. Deconstruct the given forces into their vector expressions, recalling the formula for vector expression involving the vector's magnitude and the unit vector. Hint: $\vec{T}_{BC} = T_{BC}(\frac{\vec{BC}}{BC})$ Using $\Sigma M_B = 0$ allows you to consider only forces acting perpendicular to point B and solve for reaction forces acting at point A.
  • Notice the symmetry of $T_{BC}$ and $T_{BD}$, once you derive the vector equation for one cable, the y-component of the other will have the opposite sign.
  • $\vec{T}_{BC} = T_{BC}(\frac{\vec{BC}}{BC}) = T_{BC}(\frac{-6\hat{i}-2\hat{j}+3\hat{k}}{7})$
  • $\vec{T}_{BC} = -0.857T_{BC}\hat{i}-0.286T_{BC}\hat{j}+0.429T_{BC}\hat{k}$
  • $\vec{T}_{BD} = -0.857T_{BC}\hat{i}+0.286T_{BC}\hat{j}+0.429T_{BC}\hat{k}$
  • Now we must consider the other forces acting upon the rod and their vector expressions
  • $\vec{A} = A_x\hat{i} + A_y\hat{j} + A_z\hat{z}$
  • $\vec{W} = -600\hat{k}$
  • Recall $\Sigma M_B = 0$, which allows us to solve for forces creating a moment about B
  • $(-6\hat{i} \times A_{z}\hat{k}) + (-6\hat{i} \times A_{y}\hat{j}) + (-3\hat{i} \times -600\hat{k})$
  • $(6A_{z} - 1800)\hat{j} - 6A_{y}\hat{k} = 0$
  • Solving for $\hat{j}$ and $\hat{z}$ direction $\implies$ $A_{z} = 300 N$ and $A_{y} = 0 N$
  • Recall $\Sigma F_y = 0$, and summing the y-components of $\vec{T}_{BC}$, $\vec{T}_{BD}$, and reaction forces yields
  • $-0.286T_{BC} + 0.286T_{BD} + A_y = 0$
  • $T_{BC} = T_{BD}$
  • Repeating the process for the x-direction ($\Sigma F_x = 0$) yields:
  • $-0.857T_{BC} - 0.857T_{BD} + A_x = 0$
  • $-2(0.857)T_{BC} = -A_x$
  • Finally for the summation of forces in the z-direction ($\Sigma F_z = 0$):
  • $0.429 T_{BC} + 0.429T_{BD} + A_z - 600 = 0$
  • $2(0.429)T_{BC} = 300$
  • $\implies T_{BC} = T_{BD} = 350 N$
  • $A_x = 2(0.857)(350) \implies 600 N$

question.html:
Determine the components of reaction at the fixed support. The 400 N, 500 N, 600 N forces are parallel to the x, y, z axes, respectively.

The x-component of the reaction force at A ($A_x$) is equal to:

The y-component of the reaction force at A ($A_y$) is equal to:

The z-component of the reaction force at A ($A_z$) is equal to:

The magnitude of the moment induced about the x-axis ($M_{x}$):

The magnitude of the moment induced about the y-axis ($M_{y}$):

The magnitude of the moment induced about the z-axis ($M_{z}$):
solution.html:
3D equilibrium dictates $\Sigma F_x = 0$, $\Sigma F_y = 0$, $\Sigma F_z = 0$, $\Sigma M_{sum} = 0$. What force equations can you solve if you set them equal to 0? There are a force acting upon every axis (x,y,z), use this observation to solve for all reaction forces at A. ($A = A_x\hat{i} + A_y\hat{j} + A_z\hat{z}$)
  • Recall $\Sigma M_x = 0$, which allows us to solve for forces creating a moment about the x-axis
  • $ +M_{Ax} - 500(1.25) - 600(1) = 0$
  • $ M_{Ax} = 500(1.25) + 600(1)$
  • $\implies M_{Ax}$ = +1225 N-m

Repeat this process for the other moments $M_y$ and $M_z$
  • $\Sigma M_y = 0$ allows us to solve for forces creating a moment about the y-axis
  • $ +M_{Ay} - 400(0.75) - 600(0.75) = 0$
  • $ M_{Ay} = 400(0.75) + 600(0.75)$
  • $\implies M_{Ay}$ = +750 N-m
  • $\Sigma M_z = 0$ allows us to solve for forces creating a moment about the z-axis
  • $ +M_{Az} = 0$
  • $\implies M_{Ay} = 0$

question.html:
Due to an unequal distribution of fuel in the wing tanks, the centers of gravity for airplane fuselage $A$ and wings $B$ and $C$ are located as shown. If these components have weights $W_A$ = 45,000 lb, $W_B$ = 8,000 lb, $W_C$ = 6,000 lb, determine the normal reactions of the wheels $D$, $E$, and $F$ on the ground. Round your answer to the nearest whole number.

The magnitude of the reaction force at point D ($R_D$) is equal to:

The magnitude of the reaction force at point F ($R_F$) is equal to:

The magnitude of the reaction force at point D ($R_E$) is equal to:
solution.html:
3D equilibrium dictates $\Sigma F_x = 0$, $\Sigma F_y = 0$, $\Sigma F_z = 0$, $\Sigma M_{sum} = 0$. Deconstruct the given forces into their vector expressions, and consider the moments created by the given forces. Using $\Sigma M_x = 0$ allows you to consider only forces creating a moment about the x-axis, and solve for the normal reactions.

$*Note*$ The symmetry of wheels $E$ and $D$ indicates that their induced moments will be opposite signs (counter-clockwise & clockwise).
  • $\Sigma M_{F} = 0 \implies -(14 \times R_{D}) + (14 \times R_{E}) + (8000 \times 6) - (6000 \times 8) = 0$
  • $-14R_{D} + 14R_{E} = 0$
  • $\implies R_{D} = R_{E}$
  • $\Sigma M_{y} = 0 \implies -(27 \times R_{F}) + (4500 \times 7) +(8000 \times 4) + (6000 \times 4) = 0$
  • $-27R_{F} + 371000 = 0$
  • $R_{F} = \frac{-371000}{-27}$
  • $\implies R_{F} = 13741$ lb

$*Note*$ $\Sigma M_{Z} = 0$ does not allow us to solve for any unknown variables given all forces are parallel to the rotational axis of the z-axis. Instead, utilize the summation of forces in the z-direction ($\Sigma F_{Z} = 0$)

  • $\Sigma F_{Z} = 0$
  • $R_{F} + R_{D} + R{E} - 4500 - 8000 - 6000 = 0$
  • $13741 + 2R_{E} -4500 - 8000 - 6000= 0$
  • $2R_{E} -45260= 0$
  • $R_E = \frac{45260}{2}$
  • $\implies R_{D} = R_{E} = 22630$ lb

question.html:
Find the reaction at A and find the tension in $BC$. The connection A is a smooth collar on a square shaft. $Round you answers to the nearest whole number$

The horizontal-component of the reaction at point A ($A_X$) is equal to:

The vertical-component of the reaction at point A ($A_Y$) is equal to:

The magnitude of the tension force through ($T_{BC}$) is equal to:
solution.html:
3D equilibrium dictates $\Sigma F_x = 0$, $\Sigma F_y = 0$, $\Sigma F_z = 0$, $\Sigma M_{sum} = 0$. Deconstruct the given forces into their vector expressions, recalling the formula for vector expression involving the vector's magnitude and the unit vector. Hint: $\vec{T}_{BC} = T_{BC}(\frac{\vec{BC}}{BC})$. Additionally sketch the free body diagram with all moments and reactions. The vector expression of the tension force $\vec{T_{BC}}$ $\implies$ $\hat{r_{BC}} = [(0, 1.5, 0) - (3, 0, 1)]/[\sqrt(3^2 +1.5^2 + 1^2)]$ = ($-0.857\hat{i} + 0.429\hat{j} + 0.286\hat{k}$)

$*Note*$ There are 6 total equations for equilibrium $\Sigma F_x = 0$, $\Sigma F_y = 0$, $\Sigma F_z = 0$, $\Sigma M_{sum} = 0$, $\Sigma M_x = 0$, $\Sigma M_y = 0$, $\Sigma M_z = 0$, consider what equation will allow you to solve for the reaction forces at A.
  • $\Sigma F_{x} = 0 \implies A_{X} - 0.857T_{BC} = 0$
  • $\Sigma F_{y} = 0 \implies A_{Y} + 0.429T + 200 = 0$
  • $\Sigma F_{z} = 0 \implies 0.286T - 400 = 0$
  • $\implies T = 1399 N$

Plugging our value of T back in the $\Sigma F_{X}$ and $\Sigma F_{Y}$ will find $A_{X}$ and $A_{Y}$, recall that if you have a negative answer for the magnitude of a reaction force, the force is in the opposite direction to what you initially assumed.

  • $\Sigma {M_{X}} = M_{X} + 0.429(1399)(1) \implies M_{X} = -600 Nm$
  • $\Sigma {M_{Y}} = M_{Y} + 400(3) - 0.286(1399)(3) + 0.857(1399)(1) \implies M_{Y} = -1199 Nm$
  • $\Sigma {M_{Z}} = M_{Z} + 200(3) + 0.429(1399)(3) \implies M_{Z} = 2400 Nm$

$*Note*$ A negative value for moment indicates that the true direction (clockwise or counter-clockwise) is opposite to what you initially assumed.

question.html:
A 20-kg ladder used to reach high shelves in a storeroom is supported by two flanged wheels $A$ and $B$ mounted on a rail and by a flangeless wheel $C$ resting against a rail fixed to the wall. An 80-kg man stands on the ladder and leans to the right. The line of action of the combined weight $\textbf{W}$ of the man and ladder intersects the floor at point $D$. Determine the reactions at $A,B,$ and $C$

The x-component of the reaction at point A ($A_X$) is equal to:

The y-component of the reaction at point A ($A_Y$) is equal to:

The z-component of the reaction at point A ($A_Z$) is equal to:

The x-component of the reaction at point B ($B_X$) is equal to:

The y-component of the reaction at point B ($B_Y$) is equal to:

The z-component of the reaction at point B ($B_Z$) is equal to:

The x-component of the reaction at point C ($C_X$) is equal to:

The y-component of the reaction at point C ($B_Y$) is equal to:

The z-component of the reaction at point B ($B_Z$) is equal to:
solution.html:
Draw a free-body diagram of the ladder, then write and solve the equilibrium equations in three dimensions. The combined weight of the man and the ladder is:
  • $W = -mg\hat{j} = (-981 N) \hat{j}$

You have five unknown reaction components: two at each flanged wheel and one at teh flangeless wheel. The ladder is thus only partially constrained; it is free to roll along the rails. It is, however, in equiibrium under the given load because the equation $\Sigma F_{x} = 0$ is satisfied.

  • Applying equilibirum conditions ($\Sigma F = 0$)
  • $ A_{y}\hat{j} + A_{z}\hat{k} + B_{y}\hat{j} + B_{z}\hat{k} - (981 N)\hat{j} + C\hat{k} = 0$ $textbf{(Eq. 1)}$

What equilibrium equation should you use next considering what forces are creating moments about points $A$, $B$, and $C$. Which equation will be easier to solve?
  • $\Sigma M_{B} = \Sigma(r \times F) = 0$:
  • $\implies 1.2\hat{i} \times ( B_{y}\hat{j} + B_{z}\hat{k}) + (0.9\hat{i} - 0.6\hat{k}) \times (-981\hat{j}) + (0.6\hat{i} + 3\hat{j} - 1.2\hat{k}) \times (C\hat{k})$
  • Computing the vector products yields:
  • $\implies 1.2B_{y}\hat{k} - 1.2B_{z}\hat{j} - 883\hat{k} - 589\hat{i} - 0.6C\hat{j} + 3C\hat{i} = 0$
  • $\implies (3C - 589)\hat{i} - (1.2B_{z} + 0.6C)\hat{j} + (1.2B_{y} - 883)\hat{k} = 0$ $\textbf{(Eq. 2)}$
  • Setting the coefficients of $i, j, $ and $k$ equal to zero in Eq. 2 produces the following three scalar equations, all of which state the sum of the moments about each coordinate axis must be zero:
  • $3C - 589 = 0 \implies C = +196 N$
  • $1.2B_{z} + 0.6C = 0 \implies B_{z} = -98 N$
  • $1.2B_{y} - 883 = 0 \implies B_{y} = +736 N$
  • The reactions at $B$ and $C$ are therefore
  • $B = (736 N)\hat{j} - (98 N)\hat{k}$
  • $C = (196 N)\hat{k}$
  • Setting the coefficients of $j$ and $k$ equal to zero, and plugging in $B_{y}, B_{z},$ and $C$ in Eq. 1 allows you to solve for the reaction components at A:
  • $\implies A = (+245 N)\hat{j} - (98.1 N)\hat{k}$

question.html:
The figure above shows a distributed load on a beam with a profile w(x) = $w_{0}sin(\frac{x}{2})$

The force that is equivalent to the distributed load has a magnitude of ______ kN

The equivalent force $F_{eq}$ passes through a point located at a distance of __________ to the right of point O.

The reaction at O at O_{y} is _______ kN

The reaction at B_{x} is ______ kN

The reaction at B_{y} is ______ kN
question:
what is the magnitude of the force that is equivalent to the distributed load? 
options: 
a) 0 kn 
b) 1 kn 
c) 2 kn 
d) 3 kn 

 where is the equivalent force $f_{eq}$ located with respect to point o? 
options: 
a) to the left of point o 
b) to the right of point o 
c) at point o 
d) cannot be determined 

 what is the reaction at o in the y-direction? 
options: 
a) 0 kn 
b) 1 kn 
c) 2 kn 
d) 3 kn 

 what is the reaction at b in the x-direction? 
options: 
a) 0 kn 
b) 1 kn 
c) 2 kn 
d) 3 kn 

 what is the reaction at b in the y-direction? 
options: 
a) 0 kn 
b) 1 kn 
c) 2 kn 
d) 3 kn
title: Freebody diagram force distributed
topics: Distributed Forces, Reaction Forces, Static Equilibrium

question.html:
The gate is hinged at pin O and has a distributed load as shown. It is propped at A by means of a rod AB hinged at both A and B.

The force that is equivalent to the distributed force has a magnitude of ______ kN

The equivalent force $F_{eq}$ passes through a point located a distance of __________ m vertically above point O.

What is the force at A on the gate?

24 kN directed towards A 24 kN directed away from A 18 kN directed towards A 18 kN directed away from A
question:
what is the force at a on the gate?
options:
- 24 kn directed towards a
- 24 kn directed away from a
- 18 kn directed towards a
- 18 kn directed away from a
title: Freebody diagram beam distributed

question.html:
In the figure below, a weight W is suspended from point D of a beam AD. The beam is held up by rod BC. Neglect the mass of the beam AD and rod BC. Which of the following is true (mark all that apply)

The magnitude of the force in rod BC is known The direction of the force in rod BC (i.e whether the force is tension or compression) is known. Beam AD is a two-force member Beam AD is a three force member Rod BC is a two-force member The line of action of the force in rod BC is known
question:
which of the following is true (mark all that apply)
options:
1. the magnitude of the force in rod bc is known
2. the direction of the force in rod bc (i.e whether the force is tension or compression) is known.
3. beam ad is a two-force member
4. beam ad is a three force member
5. rod bc is a two-force member
6. the line of action of the force in rod bc is known
title: Simple two-dimesnional equllibrium

question.html:
A roller of weight W is placed on a V-block as shown. The figure also shows the free body diagram of the roller. Which of the following statements are true?

The freebody diagram is correct and complete. The force N_{B} should be pointing in the opposite direction. The force N_{B} should make an angle 30 with the horizontal. The force N_{A} should be pointing in the opposite direction. The weight of the roller should be added. The force N_{A} should be pointing in the opposite direction.

A rod of weight W is hinged at A and rests on a frictionless surface at B. The figure also shows the free-body diagram of the rod.

The freebody diagram is complete and correct. The horizontal force A_{x} should be deleted. Weight should be deleted. A horizontal force B_{x} should be added. The vertical force B_{y} should be deleted. The vertical force B_{y} should be in the opposite direction. A vertical force A_{y} should be added. True or False: For a three-force member in equilibrium, the forces do not have to be in equilibrium.

True False

A hot air balloon exerts an upward force of 600N at point A and is pinned to the ground by the blue ropes. Let the tension within these ropes be labeled as T_{AB}, T_{AC}, and T_{AD}. Which of the following figures is the correct free body diagram?

A hot air balloon exerts an upward force of 600N at point A and is pinned to the ground by the blue ropes. Let the tension within these ropes be labeled as T_{AB}, T_{AC}, and T_{AD}.Determine the position vectors for each rope. Select all that apply. Refer to figure

AD = -2\hat{i} + 4\hat{j} -10\hat{k} AB = -5\hat{i} -8\hat{j} -10\hat{k} AC = 5\hat{i} +5\hat{j} -10\hat{k} AB = 5\hat{i} -8\hat{j} +10\hat{k} AC = -5\hat{i} -5\hat{j} +10\hat{k}

A hot air balloon exerts an upward force of 600N at point A and is pinned to the ground by the blue ropes. Let the tension within these ropes be labeled as T_{AB}, T_{AC}, and T_{AD}.Determine the lengths for each rope. Select all that apply.

AC = \sqrt{75} AD = \sqrt{43} AB = \sqrt{133} AC = 5\sqrt{6} AB = \sqrt{117} AD = 2\sqrt{30}

A hot air balloon exerts an upward force of 600N at point A and is pinned to the ground by the blue ropes. Let the tension within these ropes be labeled as T_{AB}, T_{AC}, and T_{AD}. Express each unit vector in Cartesian Form. Select all that apply.

T_{AB} = T_{AB}\left ( -0.434\hat{i} - 0.694\hat{j} - 0.867\hat{k}\right ) T_{AC} = T_{AC}\left ( 0.408\hat{i} +0.408\hat{j} + 0.816\hat{k}\right ) T_{AB} = T_{AB}\left ( -0.489\hat{i} +0.344\hat{j} -0.788\hat{k}\right ) T_{AD} = T_{AD}\left ( -0.183\hat{i} +0.365\hat{j} -0.913\hat{k}\right ) T_{AC} = T_{AC}\left ( 0.591\hat{i} -0.655\hat{j} -0.830\hat{k}\right )

A hot air balloon exerts an upward force of 600N at point A and is pinned to the ground by the blue ropes. Let the tension within these ropes be labeled as T_{AB}, T_{AC}, and T_{AD}. Determine the force vectors for each rope. Select all that apply.

T_{AC} = T_{AC}\left ( \frac{5\hat{i}+5\hat{j}+10\hat{k}}{\sqrt{75}} \right ) T_{AC} = T_{AC}\left ( \frac{5\hat{i}-8\hat{j}+10\hat{k}}{2\sqrt{117}} \right ) T_{AB} = T_{AB}\left ( \frac{-5\hat{i}-8\hat{j}-10\hat{k}}{\sqrt{133}} \right ) T_{AC} = T_{AC}\left ( \frac{5\hat{i}+5\hat{j}-10\hat{k}}{5\sqrt{6}} \right ) T_{AC} = T_{AC}\left ( \frac{-2\hat{i}+4\hat{j}-10\hat{k}}{2\sqrt{30}} \right )

question.html:
Consider two numbers $a = {{params.a}}$ and $b = {{params.b}}$.

What is the sum $c = a + b$?
server.py:
import random, copy

def generate():

    params = dict()
    correct_answers = dict()
    nDigits = 2
    sigfigs = 2
    data = dict(params=params, correct_answers=correct_answers, nDigits=nDigits, sigfigs=sigfigs)

    # Sample two random integers between 5 and 10 (inclusive)
    a = random.randint(5, 10)
    b = random.randint(5, 10)

    # Put these two integers into data['params']
    data['params']['a'] = a
    data['params']['b'] = b

    # Compute the sum of these two integers
    c = a + b

    # Put the sum into data['correct_answers']
    data['correct_answers']['c'] = c

    return data
question:
consider two numbers $a = 3$ and $b = -8$.
what is the sum $c = a + b$?
title: Add two numbers

    data['params']['b'] = b

Consider the two matrices:
